articles.headline: Tax Evaders Face Choice: Pay or Pray
articles.snippet: On Oct. 15, people with money in overseas banks must confess to the Internal Revenue Service and pay penalties or hope they will not be caught.
articles.abstract: On Oct. 15, people with money in overseas banks must confess to the Internal Revenue Service and pay penalties or hope they will not be caught.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many Americans dread April 15, the deadline for filing their income tax returns. But some well-heeled people are trembling over another looming tax day: Oct. 15.

articles.headline: Credit Tightens for Small Businesses
articles.snippet: Lenders are waiting to take losses in commercial real estate and credit cards before loosening up money.
articles.abstract: Lenders are waiting to take losses in commercial real estate and credit cards before loosening up money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many small and midsize American businesses are still struggling to secure bank loans, impeding their expansion plans and constraining overall economic growth, even as the country tentatively rises from its recessionary depths.

articles.headline: Russia Gas Pipeline Heightens East Europe’s Fears
articles.snippet: With a new pipeline planned along the bed of the Baltic Sea, the Russian natural gas giant Gazprom is driving a wedge between Eastern and Western Europe.
articles.abstract: With a new pipeline planned along the bed of the Baltic Sea, the Russian natural gas giant Gazprom is driving a wedge between Eastern and Western Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  With an ambitious new pipeline planned to run along the bed of the Baltic Sea, the Russian natural gas giant Gazprom is driving a political wedge between Eastern and Western Europe.

articles.headline: Deal Advice on Merrill Will Be Aired
articles.snippet: Bank of America’s board voted to reveal the legal counsel that it received about its merger with Merrill Lynch.
articles.abstract: Bank of America’s board voted to reveal the legal counsel that it received about its merger with Merrill Lynch.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facing mounting pressure from multiple investigations, Bank of America’s board has voted to reveal the legal advice that the bank received late last year in its merger with Merrill Lynch.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Disney’s Retail Plan Is a Theme Park in Its Stores
articles.snippet: The Walt Disney Company, with the help of Steve Jobs, intends to alter its approach to the shopping mall.
articles.abstract: The Walt Disney Company, with the help of Steve Jobs, intends to alter its approach to the shopping mall.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company, with the help of Steven P. Jobs and his retailing team at Apple, intends to drastically overhaul its approach to the shopping mall.

articles.headline: Cleansing the Air at the Expense of Waterways
articles.snippet: The pollutants that coal plants are scrubbing from their smokestacks are finding their way into water instead.
articles.abstract: The pollutants that coal plants are scrubbing from their smokestacks are finding their way into water instead.
articles.lead_paragraph: MASONTOWN, Pa.  For years, residents here complained about the yellow smoke pouring from the tall chimneys of the nearby coal-fired power plant, which left a film on their cars and pebbles of coal waste in their yards. Five states  including New York and New Jersey  sued the plant’s owner, Allegheny Energy, claiming the air pollution was causing respiratory diseases and acid rain.

articles.headline: In New Campaigns, Spots Take On a Rosier Hue
articles.snippet: Major companies like General Electric and Bank of America, and smaller ones, too, have begun campaigns proclaiming that America’s future is bright.
articles.abstract: Major companies like General Electric and Bank of America, and smaller ones, too, have begun campaigns proclaiming that America’s future is bright.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy is back  or so some of the country’s biggest advertisers are saying in new campaigns.

articles.headline: Don’t Fail, or Reward Success
articles.snippet: The bigger question about Wall Street bonuses is whether the enormous sums of money are proper and whether the executives have the right incentives.
articles.abstract: The bigger question about Wall Street bonuses is whether the enormous sums of money are proper and whether the executives have the right incentives.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Compensation continues to generate controversy and anger,” Lloyd Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, said last month. “And, in many respects, much of it is understandable and appropriate.”

articles.headline: Court to Hear Ex-Enron Chief Appeal
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court will consider throwing out the convictions of the former Enron chief executive Jeffrey K. Skilling for his role in the collapse of the energy giant.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court will consider throwing out the convictions of the former Enron chief executive Jeffrey K. Skilling for his role in the collapse of the energy giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to hear an appeal from Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former Enron Corporation chief executive who was sent to prison in 2006 for his role in the company’s spectacular collapse.
